Josh -

I've never looked into what it would take to integrate Cantera reactors  
with Simulink. But here's another possibility: Cantera maintains an  
internal list of all C++-level objects created, and references them by  
integers. You could in principle just pass these integers around, and  
leave the state information stored in the C++ objects.  To see how to  
access information from these objects, take a look at the files in  
Cantera/matlab/cantera/private (for example reactormethods.cpp) and  
Cantera/clib/src (especially ct.cpp and ctreactor.cpp) in the source  
distribution.

Dave



On Mar 19, 2004, at 2:25 PM, freehdom wrote:

> It's been a few months since the original message was posted, but has
> anyone made any progress with passing chemistry between two objects
> (e.g. two reactors in series) within Simulink?
>
> One solution I'm still working on is to pass two state variables
> (e.g. T,P) and the mole fraction array (from 'moleFractions(gas)')
> between objects. At the beginning of the second reactor, the 'set'
> command can be used to match the inlet of reactor 2 with the outlet
> of reactor 1. All of the variables passed are numerical values and
> may solve Brooks' problem described below. However, this assumes that
> the same mechanism is used in both reactors.
>
> Is there a more efficient and robust method of tracking the chemistry
> and thermodynamics throughout a Simulink system?
>
> Thanks -
>
> Josh
>
>> Our research group has recently been trying to integrate Cantera
>> calculations into some Matlab Simulink models, and it looks like
>> it's a somewhat difficult process to get the two of them to work
>> together in such a way as to be able to pass around mixture objects
>> via Simulink links.
>>
>> As I understand it, the primary problem appears to be that Simulink
>> wants to only handle numbers and arrays of numbers; it doesn't (as
>> far as we can find) have a capacity to pass objects.  I expect the
>> solution would be some form of creating a Cantera mixture object
>> (i.e. "heavyweight" reaction-mechanism object, as per earlier
>> discussion of copying objects to track multiple states), extracting
>> the pointer to this object in a form that Simulink can treat as a
>> number, combining it with the numerical state information to make a
>> "plain" vector representation that Simulink can pass around, and
>> then reconstructing the relevant mixture objects from this within
>> each Simulink block.  This seems like a rather complicated wheel to
>> reinvent if someone's already done it, though, particularly if
>> there are complications to it that I haven't forseen!
>>
>> So: Has anyone on the list done this (or something similar)
>> already, and if so can you offer some advice and perhaps examples
>> of how to make this work?  Does the potential solution that I have
>> seem like it's on the right track, and are there any nonobvious
>> pitfalls I should look out for?
>>
>> Thanks much,
>> - Brooks
>
